You MUST play this before Portal 2. It does a much better job at slowly teaching the mechanics to the player and the sequel does not replace the first game. You would also be confused about the lore if you didn't play this first.

This is also a small note, but in this game, the portal gun is not hitscan and shoots a projectile (unlike in Portal 2) allowing you to do some advanced tactics where you shoot a portal then go through the portal before the other portal lands, essentially acting like shooting a portal through a portal.

Portal is a really great puzzle game with fun mechanics, and still holds up despite now being almost 15 years old. It's not that long of a game, but there's also challenges and advanced maps to do after completing the story mode. I highly recommend this game, along with Portal 2, which has more puzzles, more story development, and even a level editor.

There is a reason *ninety-nine* percent of reviews for this game are positive. It is a masterpiece, and a pristine example of "less is more". Brilliant puzzles centered on single concept- create portals that let you jump between two areas. This game is genius, pure and simple, and has inspired a life-long Portal-themed following in millions of gamers.
Great puzzle game with a funny sense of humor and surprisingly really good graphics for a 13 year old game, buy it you won't regret it.

Juego clásico al que llego bastante tarde pero tengo que decir que sigue siendo un gran juego al día de hoy. La historia toma un papel secundario al servicio de las mecánicas de portales, que son excelentes, y nos hacen pensar más de lo que uno hubiese imaginado sobre el principio de conservación de movimiento.
El juego tiene 2 etapas se podría decir: una de entrenamiento y una donde se desarrolla un poco más la historia y debemos aplicar todo lo aprendido.
Se puede jugar perfectamente con controles (la compatibilidad está marcada como parcial porque el mouse es necesario para algunas partes de los menúes).
Super recomendable.

Portal is one of those very unique games. It has some humor but not in your face humor, it has some really good puzzles, a really cool idea, and a lovely atmosphere. When you play this game on full volume and really look around you just feel the isolation. You feel what Valve intended for you to feel, and I find it very amazing. This game has some of the best audio tracks I have heard in a game, and they really do their job at giving you a certain vibe. I honestly don't know what to say that hasn't already been said a million times in retrospectives and reviews. All I can really say since i laid eyes on this game...

Portal is a compelling, well-made masterpiece.  From the very beginning until the very end, I was hooked on the storyline, wondering what was going to happen next.  When I thought it was all over, I was only half way through.  It goes for the perfect amount of time - enough to leave you wanting more, but not so much that you feel bored or want to rush through it.  It is a tragic yet happy story; you grow to dislike Glados (the robot controlling the tests), but then you forgive her.  I had tears in my eyes at the end.  It is a game for all ages (although it contains dark humour in the dialogue & partially in what is written on the walls, no spoilers ;)).  The challenges you face in the game are of perfect difficulty; you have to think about all (or most) of the problems you are faced with, although you are never stuck on one problem long enough that you get bored.  You should buy the Portal pack containing Portal and Portal 2.  After playing this compelling masterpiece, I can't wait to try out Portal 2.

If you haven't played this game, play it now.

The two games in the Portal franchise are my favorite games of all time (just take a look at my profile, lolol). They center around a young silent woman named Chell who is forced to go through tests (basically just puzzles) in a scientific facility called the Aperture Science Enrichment Center. Even if you don't like puzzles, play this game. The writing, soundtrack, and design is so amazing that it's worth it.

While, in my opinion, Portal 2 is a better game than the original Portal, they are both amazing games, and it's so much more worth it to experience the first game and familiarize yourself with it's environment, mechanics, and story first.

This game is also suitable for all ages; if you're thinking about letting your child play this game but haven't played it yourself, let them. While there is some dark humor from the AI named GLaDOS who runs the facility, it's still pretty funny and it won't be a bad influence for your child (this is coming from someone who played this game for the first time at the age of 6). [spoiler] There is a part at the end of the final test chamber (19) that can be scary, but avoiding the end of this chamber should be fine. [/spoiler]  The game is only rated T for Teen because of the Sentry Turrets, which when they shoot you will show blood on the wall behind you. It's not graphic at all, just an image of a blood splatter, which any child who isn't sheltered will see anyways. This is removed from the second game entirely.

All in all, Portal is an amazing experience, and it goes on sale pretty frequently anyways, lolol.
